The patient is a 70-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, admitted to the ICU with sepsis secondary to necrotizing fasciitis of her left below-knee amputation stump. She underwent an operation for debridement and was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient developed amputation of the opposite leg and was restarted on methotrexate, but developed suspected methotrexate-induced pancytopenia and stopped the medication. She then developed neutropenic fevers and was treated with vancomycin and cefepime. The patient received leucovorin for methotrexate toxicity and overall defervesced. On [4-6], she spiked a fever to 102°F with rigors and also experienced vague abdominal discomfort. She has been on multiple antibiotics including fluconazole, meropenem, daptomycin, metronidazole, and leucovorin. 

24-hour events include removal of a subclavian line and a pan-computed tomography (CT) scan, which showed right-sided pleural effusion with associated atelectasis, but no other parenchymal changes. Laboratory results indicate neutropenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated lactate levels, and elevated liver enzymes. Fluid analysis shows elevated fibrinogen levels. An echocardiogram from [3-29] showed an ejection fraction greater than 55%
